column1: not budging with his decision to marry Marie Josephine Derisbourgh is  for current times but I can see how going against your father's or families wishes during this time period would be unreasonable.

In my opinion,  had the more  . First of all, I can't imagine deciding to marry someone my parents have never met, not tell my parents, and still ask my parents to support my lifestyle and send more money. This secrecy surrounding 's relationship may be a sign that he knows he is doing the wrong thing, or that he is being negatively influenced by Marie. Either way, this is considerable reason for  to be worried and upset, as he loves his son
because he should be allowed to make decisions about his future.

I think that  had a more   because he was just trying to keep the family together and was worried that his son was going to make a bad decision.  also comes from a background of being in a tight-knit community and of interacting with hundreds of people on a daily basis so he probably wasn't being too controlling and just wanted  to stay in Baghdad instead of leaving to live in Paris.

Based on modern society, the  of  I believe is in the right to choose whomever he'd  to marry, as love should be his motivation. However, being that this took place during the 19th century, I would say that  is expected to follow the wishes of his parents, and by not doing so, is acting unreasonable.

Based on the linked pages in the diary, it seems  's parents only wanted the best for him and he comes across as fairly ungrateful because of it; however, I don't think I can make a full judgment on who is more sympathetic without also seeing 's point of view or more about why 's relationship was so undesirable to  and those around him.
Neither person had a  . the  of  was based on culture and conflict

From my understanding of the text, it seems as if  is distraught by the fact that  wishes to marry a women he met in Paris without the consent of , his father. Furthermore, it seems as if this women is suspected of being a prostitute, and that the news of these events are becoming a great embarrassment for . It is hard to tell who is in the right or wrong, however, as we are only able to observe these events from 's perspective, which introduces a bias that, of course,  is in the wrong and  is in the right. Therefore, I don't feel as if we can conclude who is more .

It is difficult to tell, since from these pages we are only seeing the story from 's point of view.  is upset, and  does quite a few things that it appears he shouldn't do. At the same time, he is a young person, and it is unclear how much guidance and actual dialogue he has had with his father up to this point in his life.

I can see both perspectives.  was fairly young, and so he probably wasn't considering the consequences of his actions, and was just doing what he felt  doing. That being said, do think that  had the more  . I can understand why  was so stressed out, because he had very little control over what  was doing in Paris, and it was causing a scandal that affected the entire family.
